# Nose piercing

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about nose piercings of humans. For nose piercings of other
animals, see [Nose ring (animal)](/wiki/Nose_ring_\(animal\) "Nose ring
\(animal\)").

LCCN2001705685.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Woman_wearing_court_dress_and_Indian_jewelry_LCCN2001705685.jpg/230px-
Woman_wearing_court_dress_and_Indian_jewelry_LCCN2001705685.jpg)](/wiki/File:Woman_wearing_court_dress_and_Indian_jewelry_LCCN2001705685.jpg)  
Nicknames | Nostril, nose ring  
Location | [Nose](/wiki/Human_nose "Human nose") ([nostril](/wiki/Nostril "Nostril"), [nasal septum](/wiki/Nasal_septum "Nasal septum"), nose bridge)  
Jewelry | [nose stud](/wiki/Nose_stud "Nose stud"), nose bone, [Circular barbell](/wiki/Circular_barbell "Circular barbell"), [curved barbell](/wiki/Curved_barbell "Curved barbell"), [captive bead ring](/wiki/Captive_bead_ring "Captive bead ring")  
Healing | 3 to 6 months  
  
**Nose piercing** is the [piercing](/wiki/Body_piercing "Body piercing") of
the [skin](/wiki/Human_skin "Human skin") or [cartilage](/wiki/Cartilage
"Cartilage") which forms any part of the [nose](/wiki/Human_nose "Human
nose"), normally for the purpose of wearing [jewelry](/wiki/Jewellery
"Jewellery"), called a [nose-jewel](/wiki/Nose-jewel "Nose-jewel"). Among the
different varieties of nose piercings, the nostril piercing is the most
common. Nose piercing is the second most common variety of piercing after
[earlobe piercing](/wiki/Ear_piercing "Ear piercing").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Nostril
piercing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nose_piercing&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Nostril piercing")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Nose_ring%2C_northern_India%2C_early_20th_century%2C_gold%2C_rubies%2C_emeralds%2C_diamonds%2C_pearls_and_enamel%2C_HAA.JPG/170px-
Nose_ring%2C_northern_India%2C_early_20th_century%2C_gold%2C_rubies%2C_emeralds%2C_diamonds%2C_pearls_and_enamel%2C_HAA.JPG)](/wiki/File:Nose_ring,_northern_India,_early_20th_century,_gold,_rubies,_emeralds,_diamonds,_pearls_and_enamel,_HAA.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Nose_ring,_northern_India,_early_20th_century,_gold,_rubies,_emeralds,_diamonds,_pearls_and_enamel,_HAA.JPG
"Enlarge")

Early 20th century Indian nose ring

Nostril piercing is a body piercing practice for the purpose of wearing
jewelry, much like nose piercing, which is most primarily and prominently
associated with [Indian](/wiki/Indian_culture "Indian culture") culture and
fashion since classical times, and found commonly in [India](/wiki/India
"India"), [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh
"Bangladesh"), [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"), [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal
"Nepal") , [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") and throughout South
and even Southeast Asia. Nostril piercing is also part of traditional
[Australian Aboriginal](/wiki/Australian_Aboriginal "Australian Aboriginal")
culture.[1] and the culture of the Ilocano, a Muslim tribe in the Philippines.
With the diffusion, exposure and spread of Indian fashion and culture, nostril
piercing has in recent decades become popular in the wider world, as have
other forms of body piercing, after [punks](/wiki/Punk_subculture "Punk
subculture") and subsequent youth cultures in the '80s and '90s adopted this
sort of piercing. Today, nostril piercing is popular in the wider world
including South America, United States of America, Canada, the Caribbean,
Australia, Africa, Japan and Europe, with piercings being performed on either
the left or right nostril.

Historically in the [Indian Subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_Subcontinent "Indian
Subcontinent"), nose piercings are done by women only. However the spread of
this fashion has resulted in both men and women having nostril piercings in
the wider world. Several different types of nostril rings are found. Among the
most popular are the loop, the stud with an L-bar closure, the stud with a
ball closure, and the stud with a flat backing.

In India the outside of the left part of the body [?] is the preferred
position of the piercing. This is followed by some orthodox folk also because
[Ayurvedic medicine](/wiki/Ayurveda "Ayurveda") associates this location with
the female reproductive organs.[2] In India, like any other jewelry, piercings
and the jewelry are regarded as a mark of beauty and social standing as well
as a Hindu's honor to [Parvati](/wiki/Parvati "Parvati"), the goddess of
marriage. Nose piercing is still popular in India and the subcontinent. The
piercings are often an integral part of [Indian wedding](/wiki/Indian_wedding
"Indian wedding") jewelry. In [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra")
women wear very large intricate nose pieces that often cover the mouth or the
side of the face.

It is very common in [Bengali](/wiki/Bengali_people "Bengali people") women.
[Pashtun](/wiki/Pashtun_people "Pashtun people") and
[Pahari](/wiki/Pahari_people "Pahari people") women commonly have both
nostrils pierced. Many South Indian [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_people "Tamil people")
also follow this old tradition. Numerous traditions are associated with it.
Many women from the Asian subcontinent are cremated with just their nose studs
as jewelry is removed before the funeral. Indian widows usually remove their
nose studs as a sign of respect. Nose piercing has historically been strictly
forbidden among many families of [Kashmiris](/wiki/Kashmiri_people "Kashmiri
people") belonging to Butt, Dar, Lone and Mir castes settled in Pakistan as
their ancestors associated nose piercing with people of menial descent in
ancient Kashmiri society.

## Septum
piercing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nose_piercing&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Septum piercing")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Septum_piercing.jpg/170px-
Septum_piercing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Septum_piercing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Septum_piercing.jpg "Enlarge")

Large-[gauge](/wiki/American_wire_gauge "American wire gauge") septum piercing

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/FulaniWoman.jpg/170px-
FulaniWoman.jpg)](/wiki/File:FulaniWoman.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FulaniWoman.jpg "Enlarge")

Fulani woman with traditional nose ring and mouth tattoo

The [nasal septum](/wiki/Nasal_septum "Nasal septum") is the
[cartilaginous](/wiki/Cartilaginous "Cartilaginous") dividing wall between the
nostrils. Generally, the cartilage itself is not pierced, but rather the small
gap between the cartilage and the bottom of the nose (sometimes called the
"sweet spot"), typically at 14ga (1.6 mm) although it is often stretched to a
larger gauge (size). The nose has many nerves running through it, and as a
result, nose piercings can be painful, although the pain varies by individual.
This piercing heals within a month and a half to three months also depending
on the individual. It should only be stretched by 1mm at a time, and waiting
at least a month between stretches is advisable.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] If a
certain point is exceeded, usually about 8mm, the cartilage gets forced
towards the top of the nose, which can be uncomfortable.

Many types of jewelry generally are worn in a septum piercing, such as:
[Captive bead rings](/wiki/Captive_bead_ring "Captive bead ring") (CBRs),
rings that close with a bead held in the center by the tension of the ring,
circular barbells (as shown in the picture), a circular bar with a bead that
screws onto either end, a "tusk" that is a straight or shaped piece of
material generally tapered on either end, or pinchers. For large gauge
septums, many individuals choose to wear plugs, as the plugs do not weigh
their noses down, which is helpful in healing. This measure allows the
piercing not to be damaged by the sudden movement of the jewelry.

Another option is a septum retainer, which is staple-shaped. This type of nose
piercing is particularly easy to hide when desired, for example to comply with
a dress code. A septum retainer makes possible turning the jewelry up into the
nose, thus concealing it. With black jewelry flipped up into the nostrils,
this piercing can be made practically invisible. A circular barbell can also
be hidden by pushing it to the back into the nose, but it may be
uncomfortable.

Septum piercing is a popular trend among South Indian dancers
([Kuchipudi](/wiki/Kuchipudi "Kuchipudi"), [Bharatnatyam](/wiki/Bharatnatyam
"Bharatnatyam")) and among certain Native American peoples in history; the
[Shawnee](/wiki/Shawnee "Shawnee") leaders [Tecumseh](/wiki/Tecumseh
"Tecumseh") and [Tenskwatawa](/wiki/Tenskwatawa "Tenskwatawa"), for example,
had such piercings.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The septum piercing is popular in countrysides of India, Nepal, and
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"). In India such piercing is called
the 'Nathori' and popular with the Banjara ethnic groups and Adivasi tribes.
Lord Krishna and his consort Radharani are often depicted wearing the
'Nathori' style jewel nose pieces.[3]

Bengali women traditionally would wear the nathori as a sign of being a
married woman. The nathori would be gold with a tear drop that would move
along the ring. Many lower-class women in rural Bengal still keep this
tradition. This practice is now declining as many women prefer the nose studs.

In southern Nepal the septum piercing is still common. Many older women still
adorn their noses with both the septum and left nostril rings. Many women have
gold nose piercings to show their social, tribal, and religious status in
society.

### Risks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nose_piercing&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Risks")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This article **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nose_piercing&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(December 2012)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
The septum or nasal septum is the cartilaginous wall that divides the two
nostrils. The cartilage is, however, usually not pierced. It is the thin strip
of very soft and flexible skin, just between the cartilage and the bottom of
the nose, where septum piercing is mostly done. Piercing the skin instead of
the cartilage can greatly minimize the pain, as well as other discomforts
associated with this type of body piercing. This piercing should be done only
with a needle. As far as jewelry is concerned, captive bead rings, circular
barbells, plugs, tusks, curls, and septum retainer can be used.

All types of body piercings, including septum piercing, are associated with
the risk of contracting certain blood borne diseases, like hepatitis, from the
needles and piercing guns used in the procedure. This risk can be reduced by
getting the piercing done by a reputed piercer and making sure that the
piercer uses only sterile single-use needles. The next common risk associated
with almost all types of piercing is the risk of infection and pain. These
issues can be minimized greatly if piercing is done on the soft and flexible
skin that lies between the cartilage and bottom of the nose. As far as
infection risks are concerned, they can be managed with proper piercing
aftercare.

This piercing can sometimes lead to 'septal hematoma' \-- an injury to the
soft tissue within the septum that can disrupt the blood vessels to cause the
accumulation of blood and fluid under the lining. Nasal septum hematoma can
eventually cause nasal congestion and interfere with breathing along with
causing pain and inflammation. If not treated immediately, the condition can
ultimately cause formation of a hole in the septum, leading to nasal
congestion. Sometimes, that part of the nose may collapse, resulting in a
cosmetic deformity, known as '[saddle nose](/wiki/Saddle_nose "Saddle
nose")'.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Bridge
piercing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nose_piercing&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Bridge piercing")]

Main article: [Bridge piercing](/wiki/Bridge_piercing "Bridge piercing")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Erl-
piercing.jpg/220px-Erl-piercing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Erl-piercing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Erl-piercing.jpg "Enlarge")

Bridge piercing

[Bridge piercings](/wiki/Bridge_piercing "Bridge piercing") are inserted
through the skin at the top of the nose, between the eyes. Curved barbells and
straight barbells are the most commonly used in this piercing, while seamless
rings are less common.

More and more companies in the workplace have become more lenient on such
issues as piercings and the dress code. [4]

The acceptance of more visible body modifications is attributable to its
becoming a social norm. If companies did not hire employees with a tattoo or
nose piercing, the number of future workers that the companies could hire
would be limited.[5]
